newsitem.title: UK: Clarke denies he plans higher VAT on domestic fuel.
newsitem.headline: Clarke denies he plans higher VAT on domestic fuel.

text.p: Chancellor of the Exchequer Kenneth Clarke on Monday denied a report that he wanted to raise Value Added Tax (VAT) on domestic fuel to 17.5 percent from the current eight percent.
The Grocer magazine said Clarke had told one of its reporters that he intended to raise the tax.
But Clarke, who is currently in China, issued a statement dismissing the report as "absurd."
"I have accepted the view of parliament that VAT on fuel remains at eight percent," Clarke said in the statement issued by the Treasury.

A Treasury spokesman confirmed that Clarke had spoken to a reporter from Grocer magazine, but said he had not discussed VAT on fuel and had only confirmed that he did not plan to impose the tax on food items.
